meta.dc:subject: legislation
meta.dc:rights: The Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region

section.name: s2
section.heading: Interpretation
section.def: carriageway (車路) means a part of a private street, cul-de-sac or access road, used or intended to be used by vehicular traffic;
foundation (基礎) means the part of a building, street, building works or street works that—(a)is in direct contact with the ground; and(b)transmits load to the ground;
site investigation (地盤勘測), in relation to a site, means investigation of the physical characteristics of the site and includes documentary studies, site surveys and ground investigation;

subsection.leadIn: All materials used in building works or street works must be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: of a nature and quality suitable for their intended use or purpose;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: adequately mixed or prepared; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: applied, used or fixed so as to perform adequately their intended functions.

subsection.content: To ensure that subsection (1) is complied with, the materials used must be adequately tested by recognized tests.
In this Regulation, a reference to dead load is to be construed according to this section.
Dead load is a load of permanent nature.

The dead load of any building, street, building works or street works is, in each case, the total weight of its walls, floors, roofs, finishes, permanent partitions and any other permanent constructions.
For the purposes of subsection (3), the dead load must be calculated on the basis of the unit weight of the materials derived from reliable data.
In this Regulation, a reference to imposed load is to be construed according to this section.
Imposed load is a load other than dead load or wind load.

The imposed load on any building, street, building works or street works is, in each case, the greatest applied load likely to arise from its intended use or purpose (including forces exerted by the adjacent ground).
For the purposes of subsection (3), the greatest applied load must be derived from reliable data.
In this Regulation, a reference to wind load is to be construed according to this section.
Wind load is any load due to the effects of wind pressure or suction.
The wind load on any building, street, building works or street works must be based, in each case, on its response to the effect of winds from any direction.
The effect of winds referred to in subsection (3) must be suitably determined by considering the magnitude of winds having a return period of not less than 50 years.

subsection.leadIn: The minimum imposed load on a building, street, building works or street works must be whichever of the following that produces the greater adverse effect on the building, street, building works or street works—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the distributed load specified in column 3 of Table 1 in the Schedule applied uniformly on plan; or

subparagraph.content: the concentrated load specified in column 4 of the Table applied on plan over any square with a 50 mm side (or other dimension specified in that column);
the line load specified in column 4 of the Table.

subsection.leadIn: If the floor of a building is to support partitions but the positions of the partitions are not indicated on the plan of the building, the weight of the partitions—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: is to be regarded as the distributed imposed load applied uniformly on plan; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: in addition to other imposed loads—

subparagraph.content: has to be not less than one-third of the weight per metre length of the partitions uniformly distributed per square metre; and
has to be not less than 1 kPa if the floor is used for office purposes.

subsection.content: If the floor of a building is to support equipment, machinery or displaying items that will result in an imposed load greater than that specified in Table 1, the load of the equipment, machinery or displaying items must be taken into account in determining the imposed load on the floor.

Subject to subsections (2), (3), (4) and (5), in determining the total imposed load on a column, pier, wall or foundation (the member under consideration), a reduction specified in Table 2 in the Schedule may be applied to the distributed imposed load on the roof and on every floor carried by the member under consideration.

If a single span of beam supports not less than 45 m2 of floor at any level, for the purpose only of designing the beam, a reduction referred to in subsection (3) may be applied to the distributed imposed load on the floor that the beam supports.

subsection.leadIn: The reduction that may be applied is—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: 5% for each complete 45 m2 of the floor that the beam supports; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: not more than 20% in total for the floor that the beam supports.

subsection.content: For factories and workshops designed for a distributed imposed load of 7.5 kPa or more, the total imposed load must not be reduced below the value of the imposed load that is obtained if all the floors had been designed for a distributed imposed load of 7.5 kPa without the reduction specified in Table 2.

subsection.leadIn: The imposed loads must not be reduced in relation to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: floors of a building that support the equipment, machinery or displaying items referred to in section 7(3);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: floors of factories and workshops designed for a distributed imposed load of less than 7.5 kPa;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: floors used by vehicles;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: office areas used for storage and filing purposes;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: forces produced by dynamic effects;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.content: floors used for storage purposes; or

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.content: loads from partitions the positions of which are not indicated on the plan of the building.

subsection.content: A protective barrier installed to restrict or control the movement of persons must be designed to resist the minimum horizontal imposed loads specified in Table 3 in the Schedule when separately applied (relevant imposed load).
If the wind load is applicable, the protective barrier must be designed to resist the relevant imposed load or the wind load, whichever produces the greater adverse effect.

subsection.leadIn: A vehicle barrier for a carriageway, floor, driveway or ramp used by vehicles must be designed to withstand the greatest impact force anticipated, subject to the following requirements—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: the minimum design impact force on a vehicle barrier is to be [0.5 Mv2 / (δc + δb)] kN where—

subparagraph.name: M
subparagraph.content: is the gross mass in kg of the heaviest vehicle that would be allowed to use the carriageway, floor, driveway or ramp;
is the velocity of the vehicle normal to the barrier in metre per second;

subparagraph.name: c
subparagraph.content: is the deformation of the vehicle in mm; and

subparagraph.name: b
subparagraph.content: is the deflection of the barrier in mm; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the impact force is to be uniformly distributed over any length of 1.5 m and acting horizontally at the bumper height of the vehicle.

section.name: s10
section.heading: Imposed loads—forces produced by dynamic effects

subsection.content: Forces produced by dynamic effects are considered as additional imposed loads in the design of any building, street, building works and street works.

Subject to subsection (3), the forces produced by dynamic effects in a factory, workshop or other building for industrial use may be determined on the basis of information about the factory, workshop or building.

subsection.leadIn: If the forces referred to in subsection (2) are not determined on the basis of information about the factory, workshop or building—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: for the purpose only of determining the design of slabs and beams—the forces are taken to be an additional vertical imposed load of 2.5 kPa; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: for the purpose of determining the design of structural frames and foundations—the forces are taken to be an additional horizontal force (which may be assumed not to act together with the wind load) of 10% of the imposed load specified in paragraph (a), acting simultaneously on the number of floors (the number) that will produce the greatest adverse effect, where the number should be a whole number not less than 0.2 times the total number of floors subject to dynamic effects.

subsection.content: This section applies to industrial buildings and warehouses.

subsection.leadIn: A notice stating the designed distributed imposed load of a floor of an industrial building or warehouse must be displayed permanently and conspicuously at—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: each staircase of every storey of the building or warehouse; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: another appropriate place of the building or warehouse.

subsection.content: If different parts of a floor of the building or warehouse have different designed distributed imposed loads, a notice stating the designed distributed imposed load of each part of the floor must be displayed permanently and conspicuously at that part.
A notice referred to in subsection (2) or (3) must be legible and made of durable materials.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: designed distributed imposed load (設計分布外加荷載), in relation to a floor of an industrial building or warehouse, means the distributed imposed load in terms of weight per square metre, excluding the dynamic effects, for which the floor of the industrial building or warehouse is designed.

subsection.content: Subject to subsection (2), any building, street, building works or street works is not to be subject to a load beyond its proper bearing capacity.
This section does not apply in relation to any load that may be required for the purpose of testing.

section.name: s13
section.heading: Design methodology
section.leadIn: The design for any building, street, building works and street works must be in conformity with—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the laws of mechanics;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: recognized engineering principles; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: recognized engineering practices.

subsection.content: This section applies to the structure of any building, street, building works and street works.

subsection.leadIn: The structure must be capable of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: safely sustaining the combination of the dead loads, imposed loads and wind loads; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: safely transmitting the loads referred to in paragraph (a) to the ground.

subsection.content: The structure must be designed and constructed with an adequate factor of safety.

subsection.leadIn: The design and construction of the structure must not—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.leadIn: cause any cracks, deflection, deformation or other movement that may adversely affect the intended use or performance of—

subparagraph.content: the whole or any part of the building, street, building works or street works; or
the whole or any part of any other building, structure, land, street or services;
the building, street, building works or street works; or
any other building, structure, land, street or services; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: render inadequate the factor of safety of any other building, street, building works or street works.

subsection.content: The loads referred to in subsection (2)(a) are to be determined in accordance with Part 3.

section.name: s15
section.heading: Stability
section.content: A building, street, building works or street works must be designed and constructed with an adequate margin of safety against instability.

subsection.leadIn: In carrying out building works or street works—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: appropriate construction methods and procedures must be adopted; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: appropriate precautionary measures must be taken.

subsection.leadIn: Without limiting subsection (1), that subsection is not taken to be complied with in relation to a building, structure, land, street or services if—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the factor of safety or margin of safety against instability of the building, structure, land, street or services is rendered inadequate;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: damage is caused to any building, structure, land, street or services; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: crack, undue deformation or other movement of the whole or any part of the building works or street works (whether in its temporary or permanent state) occurs to the extent that the structure of the works would exceed its acceptable dimensional tolerance.

subsection.content: This section applies to a site investigation of a site in respect of building works or street works.
A site investigation that provides adequate geotechnical and any other relevant data for the design and construction of the works must be carried out in conformity with recognized standards.

subsection.leadIn: A foundation of a building, street, building works or street works must be capable of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: safely sustaining the combination of the dead loads, imposed loads and wind loads from the building, street, building works or street works, and any other loads, exerted on the foundation; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: safely transmitting the loads referred to in paragraph (a) to the ground.

subsection.leadIn: The design and construction of a foundation must take into account—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the conditions of the ground on which the foundation rests;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: its installation method; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the group effects of the foundation system.

subsection.content: The foundation must be designed and constructed with an adequate factor of safety.

subsection.leadIn: The design and construction of a foundation of a building, street, building works or street works must not—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: impair the stability of any other building, structure, land, street or services;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: cause any damage to any other building, structure, land, street or services; or

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: render inadequate the factor of safety of any other building, structure, land, street or services.

subsection.content: A site investigation of the relevant site must be carried out in compliance with section 17 before a foundation is constructed.

subsection.leadIn: The ground on which the foundation of any building, street, building works or street works rests must be capable of safely sustaining the combination of the following loads with an adequate factor of safety—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the dead loads of the building, street, building works or street works;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the imposed loads on the building, street, building works or street works;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: the wind loads on the building, street, building works or street works; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: any other loads exerted on the foundation.

section.name: s19
section.heading: Building Authority may require on-site tests

subsection.content: If the Building Authority has any doubt as to the design assumption or load carrying capacity of a foundation, the Building Authority may require tests to be carried out on-site.

subsection.leadIn: The tests may be carried out on the foundation or on the ground on which the foundation rests—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by means of imposition of test loads; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by means of any other suitable method.

subsection.content: To ascertain the performance of a foundation under load, representative foundation units of the foundation must be adequately tested by proof tests.

subsection.leadIn: The proof tests may be carried out by means of any of the following methods that is appropriate to the type of foundation—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: imposition of test loads;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: core drilling of the completed cast-in-place concrete foundation;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: any other suitable method.

subsection.content: Site formation works must be designed and constructed so as to provide an adequate margin of safety of the works and the remainder of the site during and after the construction.

subsection.leadIn: The design and construction of site formation works must not—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: cause any damage to any building, structure, land, street or services; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: render inadequate the margin of safety of any building, structure, land, street or services.

section.name: s22
section.heading: Interpretation—sections 22, 23 and 24
section.leadIn: In this section and sections 23 and 24—
section.def: minor retaining wall (小型擋土牆) means a retaining wall that meets the following descriptions—(a)the difference between the upper ground level, and the lower ground level, next to the wall does not exceed 1.5 m;(b)the average inclination of the ground on the upper ground level next to the wall does not exceed 15 degrees to the horizontal; and(c)the surcharges from the foundation or any other structures do not impose any loading on the wall;
retaining wall (擋土牆) means a permanent structure on land that retains earth or fill.

subsection.leadIn: A retaining wall must be capable of safely supporting—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the earth or fill it retains; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: other loads exerted on the wall.

subsection.leadIn: The design of a retaining wall must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: enable the function referred to in subsection (1) to be performed under the most onerous loading conditions during the wall’s construction and throughout the service life of the wall;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: be in conformity with recognized engineering principles; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: be based on data from a site investigation of the relevant site carried out in compliance with section 17.

subsection.leadIn: A retaining wall must be designed with an adequate factor of safety against—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: sliding;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: overturning;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: ultimate bearing failure; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: failure on a surface passing beneath the wall.

subsection.leadIn: The design and construction of a retaining wall must not—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: impair the stability of any building, structure, land, street or services; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: cause any damage to any building, structure, land, street or services.

subsection.content: This section applies to a retaining wall other than a minor retaining wall.

subsection.leadIn: The design and construction of a filter of a retaining wall that is placed against soil must—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: allow water to flow through the filter; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: restrain migration of particles from the soil.

subsection.content: If a drainage system is provided for a retaining wall to reduce any water pressure that may be imposed on the wall, the system must be designed and constructed so that the performance of the system can be maintained throughout the service life of the wall.
Backfill of a retaining wall must consist of material that can be compacted to form a stable fill.

subsection.leadIn: To carry away any water seepage or surface water of a retaining wall, there must be, on both the upper ground level and the lower ground level next to the wall—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: channels of suitable size; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: paving.

subsection.content: The channels or paving referred to in subsection (5) must be laid to an adequate gradient to direct the water to flow into a surface water drain.

section.name: s25
section.heading: Bulk excavation in area number 1 of scheduled areas

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: bulk excavation (大型挖掘工程) means any kind of excavation except excavation for—(a)ground investigation;(b)public utility trenches;(c)drains;(d)sewers; or(e)pile installation;

cumulative adverse effect (累積不利影響), in relation to area number 1 of the scheduled areas, means the overall adverse effects on the stability of the hillside in the area due to bulk excavation at 2 or more sites in the area.

subsection.content: Bulk excavation carried out in area number 1 of the scheduled areas must be limited to a level that minimizes the cumulative adverse effect to the area.

part.name: P8
part.heading: Requirements for External Wall, Cladding and Curtain Wall

subsection.leadIn: In this Part—
subsection.def: cladding (覆蓋層), in relation to a building, means a facing or architectural decoration additional to the structural elements of the building;
curtain wall (幕牆), in relation to a building, means a non load-bearing enclosure of the building that is fixed on to a load-bearing structure of the building;
non-combustible materials (不可燃物料) means materials that pass a recognized non-combustibility test.

subsection.leadIn: In this Part, a structure of a building is load-bearing if it bears a load that is not due to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: its own weight; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: wind pressure on its surface.

subsection.leadIn: An external wall of a building must be constructed of materials that are—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: permanent and impervious; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: non-combustible materials.

subsection.content: Adequate means of access to the outer surface of an external wall of a building or a projection from the wall must be provided for the maintenance or repair of the wall or projection.

subsection.leadIn: A cladding of a building must be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: constructed of non-combustible materials;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: of suitable thickness, strength and durability; and

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: fixed and supported in a suitable manner and sequence,

subsection.continued: so as to maintain the long-term stability and integrity of the cladding.

subsection.content: To allow differential movement between a cladding of a building and the structure of the building to which it is attached, the cladding must be permanently provided with a sufficient number of flexible joints horizontally and vertically.
Suitable metal dowels and fixings must be used to fix the cladding on to a building.

subsection.leadIn: The metal dowels and fixings referred to in subsection (3) must be—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: permanently fixed on to the structural elements of the building throughout the service life of the dowels and fixings; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: adequately protected against corrosion.

subsection.content: If the cladding of a building is exposed to weather, adequate means of access to the outer surface of the cladding or a projection from the cladding must be provided for the maintenance or repair of the cladding or projection.

subsection.leadIn: A curtain wall of a building must be capable of—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: safely sustaining the combination of the dead loads, imposed loads and wind loads; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: safely transmitting the loads referred to in paragraph (a) to a load-bearing structure of the building,

subsection.continued: without causing any deflection or deformation that may damage the wall or impair its stability.

subsection.content: A curtain wall of a building must be designed in conformity with recognized engineering principles relating to the design and structural use of materials.
To prevent water seepage or condensation from damaging a curtain wall of a building, provision must be made for the collection and discharge of any water seepage or condensed water from the wall.
A curtain wall of a building must be constructed of non-combustible materials only.

If any material used in the construction of a curtain wall of a building may be affected by electrolytic or chemical action due to its contact with other materials, the surface of the material must be satisfactorily treated or separated to prevent corrosion.
The materials used for anchors and fixings in a curtain wall system must be suitable and adequately protected against corrosion.

section.name: s31
section.heading: Curtain wall—fixing of supports and maintenance

subsection.leadIn: A curtain wall support of a building must be fixed on to a load-bearing structure of the building—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: by a cast-in anchorage in a structural concrete member of the structure; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: by welding or bolting to a structural steel member of the structure.

subsection.leadIn: The fixing of a curtain wall support to a load-bearing structure of a building must not—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: impair the structural integrity of the member of the structure to which the support is fixed; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: adversely affect the performance of the member.

subsection.content: Adequate means of access to the outer surface of a curtain wall of a building or a projection from the wall must be provided for the maintenance or repair of the wall or projection.

section.name: s32
section.heading: Walls—protection against moisture penetration
section.content: A wall of a building that may be in contact with damp must be provided with adequate protection to prevent moisture penetration.

subsection.content: The ground surface within the external walls of a building must be covered with a suitable material to prevent moisture penetration.
Adequate means must be provided to prevent ingress of water from the ground surface outside a building to the adjoining floor of the building.

To carry away any surface water on the ground surface (except in any landscaped area) outside a building, the surface must be provided with paving laid to an adequate gradient to direct the water to flow into a surface water drain.
If a room of a building is provided with a water supply, the floor of the room must be constructed so as to prevent water penetration.
The floor of a balcony (including utility platform) and a verandah of a building must be constructed so as to prevent water penetration.
The roof of a building must be designed and constructed so as to make it weatherproof.
Adequate means must be provided to prevent ingress of water from the roof of a building to the adjoining floor.
Adequate means of access to the roof of a building or a projection from the roof must be provided for the maintenance or repair of the roof or projection.

section.name: s35
section.heading: Fire resisting construction
section.leadIn: A building must be designed and constructed so as to, in case of fire—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: inhibit the spread of fire within the building and to the buildings nearby;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.leadIn: provide adequate resistance to the spread of fire and smoke—

subparagraph.content: between different buildings; and
in the building between different uses;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.leadIn: maintain the stability of the building to—

subparagraph.content: allow adequate time for safe evacuation;
allow adequate time for rescue and firefighting operation; and
avoid any consequential damage to the buildings nearby; and

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: provide adequate resistance to the spread of fire over the roof of the building to any other building having regard to the location of the building.

subsection.leadIn: This Division does not apply to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: a stage in an assembly hall;

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a vehicle parking bay for loading and unloading of goods;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: an inaccessible roof;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: an inaccessible area; or

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.content: any space (other than an accessible roof) within domestic premises for occupation by 1 family.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: inaccessible area (非開放地方) means an area that—(a)is not intended to be used for human occupation; and(b)is intended to be only accessible to personnel for maintenance or repair works;
inaccessible roof (非開放屋頂) means a roof that—(a)is not intended to be used for human occupation; and(b)is intended to be only accessible to personnel for maintenance or repair works.

subsection.content: A protective barrier must be provided at the edge of a balcony, verandah, floor, roof, staircase, landing or projection to restrict or control the movement of persons, objects and vehicles.

If the difference between 2 adjacent levels (whether or not within a building) exceeds 600 mm, a protective barrier must be provided at the higher level to restrict or control the movement of persons, objects and vehicles.

section.name: s38
section.heading: Protective barrier—design and construction
section.leadIn: A protective barrier required under section 37 must be designed and constructed so as to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: prevent a person or object from falling, rolling, sliding or slipping through the gap of the barrier; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: prevent a person from climbing over the barrier.

subsection.leadIn: This Division applies to a building in which a lift or escalator is installed or is to be installed other than—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: an amusement device, including an amusement ride as defined by section 2(1) of the Amusement Rides (Safety) Ordinance (Cap. 449);

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: a belt, bucket, scoop or roller conveyor or any similar machine;

paragraph.name: c
paragraph.content: a hoist, including a skip hoist, used mainly for charging furnaces or similar appliances;

paragraph.name: d
paragraph.content: a hoist used solely for lifting or feeding material directly into a machine or used solely for both of those purposes;

paragraph.name: e
paragraph.leadIn: a lift the height of travel of which does not exceed 3.5 m and that—

subparagraph.content: does not pass through any floor; and
is used solely for the carriage, stacking, loading or unloading of any goods or materials or any 2 or more of those purposes;

paragraph.name: f
paragraph.leadIn: a lift the height of travel of which does not exceed 3.5 m and that—

subparagraph.content: does not pass through any floor; and
is used solely for raising motor vehicles;

paragraph.name: g
paragraph.leadIn: a lift that is provided, in connection with a building under construction, solely—

subparagraph.content: for carrying persons employed in the construction of the building;
for carrying materials used in connection with the construction of the building; or
for carrying persons referred to in subparagraph (i) and materials referred to in subparagraph (ii);

paragraph.name: h
paragraph.content: a ramp that is connected to a wharf or pier;
a stage or orchestra lift;

paragraph.name: j
paragraph.content: a stairlift with a guided carriage for use by persons (whether or not with a wheelchair) that travels substantially along the direction of a flight of stairs; or

paragraph.name: k
paragraph.leadIn: a lifting platform for carrying persons with a disability (whether or not with a wheelchair) if—

subparagraph.content: the platform travels between different levels; and
the difference between the highest and lowest of the levels does not exceed 2 m.

subsection.leadIn: In this Division—
subsection.def: associated equipment or machinery (相聯設備或機械), in relation to a lift or escalator, has the meaning given by section 2(1) of the Lifts and Escalators Ordinance (Cap. 618);

restricted space (限進空間) means—(a)in relation to a lift—the lift shaft and the space containing the associated equipment or machinery of the lift; or(b)in relation to an escalator—the space containing the associated equipment or machinery of the escalator.

section.name: s40
section.heading: Design and construction in connection with lift and escalator

subsection.leadIn: A building must be designed and constructed so as to—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: provide adequate structural strength, space, protection, access and ventilation for the safe operation, inspection and maintenance of a lift or escalator; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: ensure that the restricted space of a lift or escalator is inaccessible except for inspection, maintenance, repair or rescue.

subsection.content: If a lift or escalator is added to a building after the completion of the building, the design and construction relating to the addition must comply with subsection (1).

section.name: s41
section.heading: Warning notices on use of lift and escalator

subsection.leadIn: A notice must be displayed permanently at a conspicuous location of a door or other form of access to the restricted space of a lift or escalator in a building, to caution against—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the danger of entering the restricted space; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the danger of interfering with the operation of the lift or escalator.

subsection.content: A notice must be displayed permanently at a conspicuous location of every entrance of a lift to caution against using a lift when there is a fire.
A notice referred to in subsection (1) or (2) must be legible and made of durable materials.

If a ground treatment is to be carried out to improve the load carrying capacity of a ground, adequate proof of the suitability of the method and materials to be used for the treatment must be given to the Building Authority.
If a ground treatment has been carried out on a ground, the Building Authority may require adequate tests of the ground to be carried out.
If a ground treatment may affect any building, structure, land, street or services, adequate precautionary measures must be taken.
A well associated with a building or building works must not be sunk or reopened except with the permission of the Building Authority.

subsection.leadIn: The design, construction and operation of a well must not—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: impair the stability of any building, structure, land, street or services; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: cause any damage to any building, structure, land, street or services.

subsection.content: A well must not be sunk in the vicinity of a septic tank, cesspool, sewage sump or in a contaminated ground.
A well must be provided with adequate means to prevent surface water or sullage water from getting into the well from its top opening.
A well must be properly lined to prevent contamination.
If a well is likely to be adversely affected by accumulation of particles, a suitable filter must be provided.
A well must be designed and constructed so as to prevent unauthorized entry.

subsection.leadIn: This section applies to a chimney and flue—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: the internal diameter, breadth or width of which exceeds 200 mm; or

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: the height of which exceeds 3 m.

subsection.leadIn: A chimney of a building—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must be constructed, positioned or shielded so as to prevent ignition of any part of the building or any other building; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must be constructed so as to ensure that the temperature of its outer surface would not reach a level that may cause any danger to a person in or near the building.

subsection.leadIn: A flue of a building, whether installed inside or outside the building—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must be constructed, positioned or shielded so as to prevent ignition of any part of the building or any other building; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must be positioned or shielded so as to minimize the risk of accidental damage to the flue and the danger to a person in or near the building.

subsection.content: To prevent a fire in a building, a flue must terminate at a position so that the products of combustion will not enter the windows or openings, fresh air inlets, mechanical ventilation inlets or exhausts of the building or any other building.

subsection.leadIn: In this section—
subsection.def: chimney (煙囱) means—(a)a structure that performs the same functions as a flue; or(b)a structure enclosing a flue or flues;
flue (煙道) means a duct through which products of combustion pass or are intended to pass before reaching the open air;
products of combustion (燃燒產物) include—(a)smoke;(b)fumes from a stove, oven or any other cooking apparatus; and(c)vitiated air.

section.name: s45
section.heading: Fireplace
section.content: A hearth or fireplace recess in a building must be constructed so as to prevent a fire in the building or any other building.

section.name: s46
section.heading: Habitation by vermin
section.content: A building must be constructed so as not to provide a place of habitation for vermin.

section.name: s47
section.heading: Duct
section.leadIn: If the size of a duct allows a person to enter the duct, the duct—

paragraph.name: a
paragraph.content: must be fitted with an access opening to allow a person to enter it; and

paragraph.name: b
paragraph.content: must be constructed so as to bear the weight of the person.
